#### Section 1: Bottom-up: synthesis and self-assembly
The generation of nanostructures can be divided into two separate but
equally important categories: the top-down processes such as
photolithography that make deterministic patterns in two or three
dimensions in small quantities on a wafer, and the bottom-up processes
such as self-assembly that make copious amounts of structures in a
flask. This chapter discusses processes of synthesis and
self-assembly---i.e., **bottom-up**---of nanoscale materials, along with
an application which has transformed the delivery of cancer therapeutics
and vaccines. Namely, nanomedicine. For a video primer to this chapter,
visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/SGomGeqy3U8)

In order to have nanotechnology, you need to be able to create
nanostructures. In the previous chapter, we covered some of the most
common ways in which nanostructures are produced from top-down methods.
"Top down" means that, like a marble sculpture, the structure in some
sense already exists inside a slab of material. All that is needed is to
cut away the extra material, leaving the desired structure(s).[^13.1.1] The
process is sometimes called **subtractive**, in that the bits that are
cut away are usually discarded. To describe the process in a less
pejorative light than what is implied by the word *subtractive*,
photolithography and electron-beam lithography are also often called
**deterministic**, meaning that the engineer (or artist) knows where the
materials are going to end up in the final structure. Typical materials
that are amenable to top-down nanofabrication include silicon, silicon
dioxide or quartz, other oxides, and metals. Polymeric films such as
photoresists are also patterned by the quintessential top-down method,
photolithography. Thus, top-down nanofabrication processes are used in
some of the most sophisticated manufacturing schemes ever devised for
commercial products (i.e., microchips).

In contrast to top-down nanofabrication, so-called bottom-up processes
use thermodynamics, electrostatics, shape recognition, and other
naturally occurring phenomena to determine---as if programmed---where
everything will end up. In bottom-up processes, smaller, unstructured
components become converted through minimal external intervention into
functional, higher-order structures. A very simple example might be spin
coating a photoresist film. That is, a polymer in solution, which
consists of disordered molecules floating around, gets cast into a two
dimensional solid film. This film has macroscopic dimensions and a
morphology whose microscopic structure is determined by the molecular
details of the materials from which it is made. Figure (13.1)
illustrates the differences between top-down and bottom-up approaches to
nanofabrication, along with some examples of each.

(Figure 13.1) 
>>>image(top-down bottom-up.png.0)

### 13.1.1. Biological structuresThe quintessential example of
bottom-up fabrication is the self-assembly of biological structures. One
prominent example is the three-dimensional shape adopted by protein
molecules. Protein structure is remarkable because every chemically
identical protein molecule (i.e. made up of the same sequence of amino
acids) will fold up to form a physically identical structure, whereas
the physical structures assumed by conventional polymer chains are
highly variable, so that polymer structure is understood as a
statistical distribution among many possible chain conformations.
Moreover, the self-assembly of protein molecules is **hierarchical**,
with many smaller self-assembled structures self-assembling to make up
the final structure. Examples of these multilevel self-assembled
structures are alpha helices, beta sheets, and supramolecular
arrangements where multiple peptide chains form a larger, quaternary
structure (see Figure (13.2)). The self-assembly of biomolecules is an
example from nature that nanotechnologists use as a proof-of-principle
and indeed inspiration that a bottom-up process might be used to create
almost any complex structure with wide-ranging functionality.

(Figure 13.2) 
>>>image(protein.png.0)

### 13.1.2. Micelles, vesicles, and other amphiphilic structures
Moreover, protein-based nanostructures---and even RNA-based
nanostructures in cells---are used in biological systems in the form of
enzymes and other types of molecular machines.[^13.1.2] Such an incredible
array of functions further motivate engineers, chemists,
nanotechnologists, and biotechnologists. In fact, the physical structure
of the cell itself is a supreme example of bottom-up nanofabrication.
The cell membrane is an example of a **bilayer vesicle**, part of a
family that includes micelles and inverted micelles, see Figure (13.3).
It forms because the molecules that make it up are **amphiphilic**,
meaning that part of the molecule likes water and the other part likes
nonpolar media. In the case of a bilayer vesicle, the amphiphiles pair
up such that the hydrophobic tail groups point toward each other to make
up the "skin" of the vesicle. At the same time, the ionic head groups
point toward the exterior and interior of the vesicle, where the water
is. The principles at play are the same as those which determine the
separation of oil and water in a bottle of salad dressing.

(Figure 13.3) 
>>>image(bilayer vesicle.png.0)

### 13.1.3. Block copolymers Another form of molecular self-assembly
which we have encountered already is the formation of higher ordered
nanostructures from block copolymers. For example, a polymer chains
composed of two or more chemically dissimilar blocks can be engineered
to self-assemble themselves into various shapes. Arrays of cylinders,
lines, lamellar (layer-cake like) structures, and three-dimensional
arrays of spheres can all be generated. Addditionally, the contiguous
gyroidal structures that can be formed by block copolymer assemblies in
3-dimensions are not only aesthetically interesting. Many of these
structures are useful in technological applications, such as low
dielectric layers in telecommunications, graphics processors, and
printed circuit boards for low-loss transmission of data.

### 13.1.4. Self-assembly Central to the concept of bottom-up
nanofabrication is the concept of **self-assembly**. Self-assembly is
the process by which simple structures become more complex structures.
That is, how lower-order structures like molecules and nanoparticles
come together to form higher-ordered structures like micelles, bilayer
vesicles, molecular monolayers, and the shapes formed by block
copolymers, and even proteins, cell membranes, and larger biological
structures. The difference between "self-assembly" and more familiar
words such as "synthesis" and "formation" is not always clear. However,
it is generally taken that true self-assembly refers to
thermodynamically reversible processes, whereas synthesis often involves
changes in oxidation states, the formation of covalent bonds, and those
which are difficult to reverse or undo without significant effort.
However, as this chapter is not specifically about self-assembly, but
rather about fabrication using bottom-up processing techniques, we will
start with some relevant aspects of synthesis---i.e., of molecules and
nanoparticles---which is often the first step in bottom-up processes.
That is, making the parts that ultimately go into the final manufactured
product.

[^13.1.1]: I think the idea of using tools to reveal what an artist
    visualized as already existing within a slab of marble originated
    with Michelangelo.

[^13.1.2]: Indeed, the ribosome---which translates mRNA molecules into
    protein molecules---is an incredible example of natural molecular
    manufacturing!

#### Section 2: Synthesis
The process of synthesis in principle encompasses everything ever used
in the field of chemistry to make stuff: drugs, plastics, fuels,
coatings, food additives, and so forth. However, we find that once we
limit ourselves to the synthesis of higher order structures with
nanoscale dimensions (dimensions larger than typical molecules), we
whittle the list down to only a few of the most common examples. These
include nanoparticles based on metals and semiconductors (**metallic
nanoparticles** and **quantum dots**), along with those made from
polymers (including individual polymer chains and sphere-like
**dendrimers**).

### 13.2.1. Synthesis of zero dimensional metal nanoparticles

Since the development of **electron microscopy** (including scanning
electron microscopy, **SEM**, and transmission electron microscopy,
**TEM**), chemists have been interested in synthesizing metallic
nanoparticles whose three-dimensional shapes can be readily verified. In
general, these methods involve the chemical reduction of a metal salt
where the metal comes out of the bottle in oxidized form (e.g., gold
nanoparticles are made using chloroauric acid, H\[AuCl$_4$\], where gold
has the oxidation state of 3+). It is typical to add a polymer into the
mixture to prevent aggregation of the particles during growth and
thereafter. The polymer prevents aggregation by polymer-mediated steric
forces, a type of repulsive force of entropic origin covered in Chapter
3. Very often, one or more types of surfactants or metal ligands are
used as well.[^13.2.1] Often, a surfactant to afford solubility is used as
well. The ligands or surfactants are often amphiphilic molecules such as
an alkane thiol (RSH) or a trialkylphospine oxide. Such molecules bind
selectively to certain crystallographic faces of the growing crystalline
nanoparticle and thus block further growth at that face. The other faces
grow in unencumbered. This strategy is used as a means of obtaining
nanoparticles with specific shapes.[^13.2.2] Using these strategies, many
types of metallic nanoparticles have been produced: nanowires,
nanoplatelets, nanocubes, pyramids, and other polyhedra. There are ways
to synthesize nearly any type of particle. These particles have many
uses. For example, silver nanoparticles are used in clothing and some
stuffed children's toys as antimicrobial agents. Silver nanowires are
used commercially as transparent conductive electrodes.[^13.2.3] Small
metallic nanoparticles also exhibit a quintessentially nanoscale
phenomenon called **localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR)**, in
which incoming light causes an oscillation of the conduction electrons
at the interface between the metal and the external environment (i.e.,
air). The LSPR phenomenon is responsible for the bright colors exhibited
by some types of metallic nanoparticles. The effect is potentially
useful in next-generation forms of medical imaging, light-trapping for
solar cells, and even drug delivery.

### 13.2.2. Synthesis of semiconductor nanocrystals or quantum dots

Another class of materials which are commonly synthesized by
conventional chemical techniques include the synthesis of quantum dots.
The exemplar of a quantum dot combines a metal (e.g., cadmium, lead) and
a chalcogenide (i.e., sulfur, selenium, or tellurium). The typical
example is cadmium selenide (CdSe)[^13.2.4]. The synthesis is pretty
straightforward and can be done in an undergraduate lab. To begin, one
makes separate solutions of a selenium and cadmium precursors. Elemental
selenium comes as a powder and is dissolved in trioctylphosphine, which
is a liquid. Separately, a cadmium salt such as cadmium acetate
dihydrate is mixed with oleic acid and octadecene. The two precursor
solutions are added simultaneously to a flask with additional solvent
held at an elevated temperature. Once the precursors are combined, the
solution takes on a color, which evolves over time as the quantum dots
increase in size. Aliquots (small samples) can be taken at regular time
intervals. The longer the reaction goes, the larger the quantum dots
will be, and the redder---i.e., lower energy---the emitted fluorescent
photons. The total reaction takes about 10 minutes. Once the reaction is
quenched, the quantum dots are close to **monodisperse**, meaning they
are all about the same size.[^13.2.5]

### 13.2.3. Synthesis of polymers

Polymers are a fundamental building block of nanoengineered systems.
They play roles in both top-down nanofabrication in the form of
photoresists, and also in structures produced by bottom-up methods such
as liposomes and other nanoscale drug-delivery vehicles. Biological
macromolecules share many of the same properties as synthetic polymers,
and the important phenomena in both types of macromolecules are the
result of intermolecular, interparticle, and entropic forces that occur
on the nanoscale. In fact, the quintessential measurement of the size of
a polymer molecule in solution is the **radius of gyration**, which has
a scale of several nanometers tens of nanometers.

In our discussion of synthetic nanoparticles such as quantum dots, we
made a point of emphasizing the fact that they all ended up about the
same size (i.e., a **dispersity** close to 1). For the synthesis of
polymers, most high-volume methods of synthesis, including all
step-growth polycondensation reactions, along with free-radical
polymerization reactions, produce molecules with a range of sizes and
thus values for dispersity \>1. There are however a few methods that
generate samples with near **monodispersity**. Most of these methods are
characterized as living polymerizations (such as **anionic
polymerization**, where the formation of bonds between monomers is
mediated by a formal negative charge) and controlled radical
polymerization, which, incidentally, are those types of reactions which
are also amenable to the production of block copolymers. In the living
or controlled radical polymerization, the reactive end of the growing
chain reacts one at a time with monomer molecules in solution. This
sequence of the addition of monomers contrasts with a free radical
polymerization in which polymer chains grow at different times and
lengths before spontaneously terminating. With an anionic or controlled
radical polymerization, the reaction can be stopped after the chains
reach a predetermined size. This approach permits a kind of chemical
nanotechnology in which the ability for polymers to, for example,
interact with cells, drug molecules, or chemical analytes can be
precisely tuned.

### 13.2.4. Dendrimers

A **dendrimer** is a three dimensional polymer that is designed to be
monodisperse (see Figure (13.4)). This structure is made in a multistep
synthesis in a way that resembles the formation of the bushy top of a
tree, which grows gradually over many years. Each branch forks to form
new branches. The starting material is a multivalent core unit to which
a number of multivalent units are reacted. These units have a protecting
group on them so that they stop growing after a single reaction. The
protecting groups are then removed and then another round of reaction
takes place, which generates additional branch points. These levels of
branching are called **generations**. After multiple generations, one is
left with three-dimensional polymer blobs with precisely defined
structures. These materials have many potential uses, such as particles
for drug delivery and for imaging applications.

(Figure 13.4) 
>>>image(dendrimer.png.0)

[^13.2.1]: A ligand is a molecule that binds to something, typically
    non-covalently.

[^13.2.2]: The inclusion of such additives is not completely necessary if the
    crystal in phases add atoms at unequal rates without such
    interventions.

[^13.2.3]: A transparent conductive electrode (TCO) is a thin film which has,
    say, 90+% transparency in the visible region of the electromagnetic
    spectrum. They are critical components of display technologies
    (there are TCOs covering the front and back of the screen you are
    looking at right now) and thin-film solar cells. The most common TCO
    is tin-doped indium oxide ("ITO"), which is expensive because of all
    the indium it uses. In contrast, a thin film of silver nanowires
    uses maybe a few percent, max, of silver than ITO does of indium.
    When deposited on a flat piece of glass, silver nanowires form a
    percolated pathway and allow electricity to travel from one side of
    the film to the other. The space between the nanowires is optically
    transparent.

[^13.2.4]: Cool people pronounce it "cad-sell."

[^13.2.5]: This reaction sequence was adapted from Landry, Morrell et al.
    Simple syntheses of CdSe Quantum Dots *J. Chem. Ed.*, **2014**,
    *91*, 274-279.\]

#### Section 3: Self-assembly
Self-assembly is superficially similar to synthesis, except that in
self-assembly, the bonds that form are ionic or van der Waals as opposed
to metallic or covalent. Moreover, such bonds based on electrostatic
interactions tend to be more transient and are more likely to be
reversible than covalent bonds. Reversibility is the hallmark of
processes of self-assembly. For example, ionic bonds and van der Waals
bonds permit the materials to reconfigure in response to environmental
conditions, such as changes in local pH, temperature, or stimulation by
optical wavelengths. Here, we discuss a few types of self-assembly of
interest in nanoengineered systems: the formation of micelles and
bilayer vesicles, the formation of self assembled monolayers on metals
and silica, and the separation of unlike polymers, including the
formation of block copolymer micro- and nanostructures.

### 13.3.1. Micelles

A micelle is a self-assembled structure containing amphiphilic
molecules. The name **amphiphile** is derived from Greek meaning that
the molecules "love" two different kinds of media---possessing both
hydrophilic and lipophilic[^13.3.1] properties---at the same time. A
quintessential example of an amphiphilic molecule is sodium dodecyl
sufate (SDS, also known as sodium lauryl sulfate), the active component
of soap. These molecules contain a hydrophilic end group such as a
sulfate or phosphate. This negatively charged hydrophilic group
associates with the partial positive charges of the hydrogen atoms of
nearby water molecules. The dodecyl group of the SDS molecule, on the
other hand, is hydrophobic. Water molecules, for their part, prefer to
be associated with each other because they can form cages of hydrogen
bonds which---as we discussed in Chapter 2---are highly energetically
favorable. Moreover, the formation of such ordered, cage-like structures
around hydrophobic and amphiphilic solutes allows other water molecules
to float away in solution. The freedom these water molecules have is
entropically favorable. At sufficiently high concentrations of
SDS---**the critical micelle concentration (CMC)**---these alkyl chains
associate with one another and form a sphere called a **micelle**. The
interior of the sphere can trap hydrophobic grease, waxes, and oils,
which is why SDS and other similar amphiphiles are used so commonly in
soaps, shampoos, and detergents.

To review, the driving force for this archetypal process of
self-assembly is both electrostatic *and* entropic. It is electrostatic
because the dipoles of the water in the surrounding media coordinated
with the charged groups of the polar head group of the amphiphile, and
entropic because the water molecules that would have preferred to
associate with the hydrophobic tail groups of the amphiphile are now
free to circulate freely in the water bulk. Micelles are thus spherical
objects with a hydrophobic core and a hydrophilic exterior. Such is the
situation in aqueous environments. However, when amphiphiles like SDS
are placed in some types of non-polar or hydrophobic media---e.g.,
certain types of organic solvents---the micelle turns inside out. That
is, an **inverted micelle**, with the hydrophobic tails on the outside
and the hydrophilic groups on the inside.

#### Critical micelle concentration (CMC)

It is important to note however that micelles do not form immediately
with the first few molecules of amphiphile added to water. The reason is
that entropy is powerful and if molecules can afford energetically to
remain free in the solution, they will do so. Moreover, there are many
interfaces in a solution of water with which an amphiphilic molecule
might profitably interact. (That is, with respect to electrostatic
potential energy.) For example, the interface with the glass or plastic
container and also the interface between the liquid and the air. Once
these surfaces are saturated with molecules at a surface density of
around 10$^{14}$ cm$^{-2}$, and the solution holds as many individual
amphiphilic molecules as it can, micelles start to form. This
concentration is known as the **critical micelle concentration** (CMC),
and again, is the concentration of molecules in solution at which
micelles start to form. The CMC is a parameter that depends on the shape
of the amphiphilic molecule and its interfacial free energy with the
liquid medium (that is, water in most cases).

We note that the concentration at any point reflects only the
concentration of monomers, micelles, and monomers in micelles that are
actually in the solution. Those molecules which had adsorbed to the
vessel walls or the interface with the air do not count. Also, it is
very easy to disrupt the concentration of micelles by introducing other
interfaces into the mix. For example, blowing a fine mist of air bubbles
from a hose in the water will immediately cause molecules of the
amphiphile to associate with the bubble, even if those amphiphilic
molecules have to be recruited away from existing micelles in solution.
The same goes for other hydrophobic solutes, like oil droplets, which
will also tend to pull molecules out of the solution and toward these
interfaces. Note that molecules associated with interfaces---including
the liquid-air interface at the top of a container, the sidewalls of the
container, and the surfaces of any bubbles or droplets of gas or
oil---do not count toward the total concentration of amphiphilic
molecules (or any molecules) in solution.

### 13.3.2. Bilayer vesicles

The type of structure formed by amphiphiles in solution depends not only
on the chemical composition of the amphiphile, but also on its shape.
For example, a molecule like sodium dodecyl sulfate looks approximately
like a narrow cone, in terms of electron density: the polar sulfate
group is relatively large compared to the skinny alkyl chain. However, a
**phospholipid** which has a large head group but *two* alkyl chains, is
more uniform along its length and can thus be approximated as a
cylinder. So, a conical amphiphile might form a spherical structure
(micelle), whereas a cylindrical amplifier will would form a
**bilayer**. A bilayer by itself would not be stable because the edges
would still be relatively high in surface energy. Thus, a bilayer balls
up on itself to form a **bilayer vesicle**. Bilayer vesicles were
believed to form some of the first proto-cells on the early Earth and
also serve as the phospholipid bilayer membrane of biological cells.
Bilayer vesicles are also used as the scaffolds of **liposomes**,
self-assembled nanoparticles used ubiquitously to encapsulate drugs for
chemotherapy or mRNA vaccines.

### 13.3.3. Molecular monolayers

A critical type of structure in micro and nanofabrication, and also in
biophysical studies in the biopharmaceutical industry is the **molecular
monolayer**. There are two major types of molecular monolayers of
importance in these industries as well as research laboratories:
self-assembled monolayers of alkene thiolates on coinage metals (and
also self-assembled monolayers of electrostatically coordinated alkyl
phosphates on oxide surfaces of other metals) and covalently bound
molecular monolayers of silanes on oxidized silicon,

#### Self assembled monolayers of alkane thiolates on coinage metals

The most famous type of self-assembled monolayer is that of a
sulfur-containing small molecule and its interaction with a coinage
metal surface. The class of elements known as coinage metal---often
called **noble metals**---include gold, silver, palladium, and
platinum.[^13.3.2] Self-assembled monolayers ("SAMs" for short, see Figure
(13.5)), are formed because of a very strong interaction that occurs
between the empty molecular orbitals of a coinage metal, and the lone
pairs of electrons of the sulfur atom. The bond between the sulfur and
metal atoms is nearly as strong as a covalent bond. Yet, these bonds can
be swapped around so that the molecules making up the SAM are
effectively mobile on the surface. They can also be exchanged. For
example, if a surface containing a SAM with an alkyl chain length of 4
carbon atoms is placed in a bath with molecules with side chain lengths
of 8 atoms, the surface will eventually be replaced with molecules with
8 carbon atoms, simply because there is a huge reservoir of molecules in
solution relative to those on the surface.[^13.3.3]

(Figure 13.5) 
>>>image(SAMs.png.0)

The strong bond formed between the sulfur atom and the metal is only
part of the driving force for the formation of a SAM. The other part is
the favorable van der Waals interactions between the alkyl side chains.
Remember from Chapter 2 that the strength of a van der Waals interaction
between molecules increases by about $\frac{3}{2}kT$ per CH$_2$ unit.
So, the longer the alkyl chains in the SAM, the greater the *cohesive
energy* holding the SAM together.

The most common molecular precursor from which SAMs are made is the
**alkane thiol, RSH**, where R can be any alkyl group. When the molecule
binds, it is believed that the hydrogen atoms come off, pair up, and
leave as H$_2$ gas. It is also possible to form a SAM from an alkyl
disulfide, RS-SR, where the bond between sulfur atoms breaks and each
leftover RS group binds to the surface individually. In this case, there
is no hydrogen atom to be released. A type of SAM which binds more
weakly to the surface, but which forms nonetheless is a dialkyl sulfide,
or R$_2$S, where each sulfur atom has two alkyl groups. In all cases,
the R group can be tailored to contain functional groups. This
capability is absolutely key to the usefulness of SAMS: because of the
strong interaction energy of sulfur with metals, it is possible to place
nearly any functional group at the surface of any metallic nanoparticle
or surface at a very high density. For example, SAMs may contain
initiation sites for polymerization, binding of ligands for protein
interaction, and sites to tailor the surface energy.

#### Other SAMs

There are other types of SAMs, notably negatively charged ions on oxide
surfaces. For example, alkyl chains terminated with a charged
phosphonate ion bind to oxide surfaces (e.g., titanium oxide), but with
less strength than the bond of thiols to coinage or noble metals.

### 13.3.4. Silane monolayers on silicon oxide

Silicon is among the most important materials in modern technology and
ubiquitous in nanoengineered systems, particularly those made by
top-down methods of fabrication. The usefulness of silicon derives from
its semiconducting properties---as in solar cells, microprocessors, and
memory chips---but also the ability to form ultraflat wafers and to
fashion it into a variety of microdevices by photolithography. An
important enabling aspect of silicon nanotechnology is the ability to
modify the surface properties. For example, the adhesion of silicon to
other materials (or other silicon devices) can be modified by changing
the dipole moment at the surface and thus the surface energy. The
primary way to do this is by modification with a molecular monolayer.

Before discussing the types of silane monolayers, it is worthwhile to
take a closer look at the silicon surface. Like most metals, which are
quickly oxidized in air, the surface of silicon is covered with a
**native oxide** layer around 2 nm thick. This oxide layer grows on most
metals in ambient air simply because of the presence of oxygen in the
atmosphere. The thickness of this native oxide layer is said to be
**self-limited**---it never gets any thicker unless it is exposed to
plasma, a chemical treatment, or heated to several hundred degrees.[^13.3.4]
The oxidized surface is terminated with OH groups, so the last atom on
an oxidized surface is a highly polar species reminiscent of an alcohol.
The hydrogen atom can donate a hydrogen bond to a negatively charged ion
and the lone pairs of the oxygen atoms can be used to form covalent
bonds with reactive, **electrophilic**, molecules.

The typical reagents used to modify the surface of silicon are also
based on silicon, that is **silane monolayers**. Silane molecules that
make up silane monolayers have the general form RSiX$_3$, where X is
usually Cl or RO. That is, it is either a trichloro or trialkoxy silane.
This valency of three allows the silane to react with three terminal
OH---**silanol**---groups on the surface.

[^13.3.1]: More commonly described in nanoengineering as the antonym to
    hydrophilic, **hydrophobic**

[^13.3.2]: While copper is sometimes considered a coinage metal for these
    purposes, it tends to oxidize more so than the others, and is less
    amenable to the formation of self assembled monolayers.

[^13.3.3]: The surface density of atoms or densely packed groups on a surface
    is ca. 10$^{14}$ cm$^{-2}$.

[^13.3.4]: The self-limited nature of the native oxide arises because once
    the oxide reaches a certain thickness, electrons are unable to
    exchange by **quantum tunneling** with the oxygen in the ambient
    air.

#### Section 4: Biomedical nanotechnology
One of the major uses envisioned for nanoparticles of various types is
in **biomedical nanotechnology**. Biomedical nanotechnology includes a
range of devices, such as wearable and implantable sensors of various
physiological signals and chemical analytes (a field collectively known
as **bioelectronics**), as well as *ex vivo* (outside the body) sensors
used in genetic sequencing and other forms of molecular diagnostics.
Nanoengineered solutions have also been proposed and successfully
commercialized as **biomaterials** for medical instruments (e.g., which
interface with the brain or nervous system) as well as constructs for
**tissue engineering** and **regenerative medicine**. Given the scope of
nanomedicine---for which there are several excellent textbooks---our
focus in this section will be on the use of nanoparticles of various
types as agents for drug delivery, targeting, and evasion of the immune
system. Here, we will give a brief glimpse of the rationale, materials,
and successes of these approaches, but know that there is a much larger
body of books, literature, and videos on YouTube and other places, for
those interested.

### 13.4.1. Nanomedicine in cancer therapeutics

Cancer is among the leading causes of mortality worldwide. The
difficulty in treating cancer arises to a large extent because the
cancerous tissue is embedded within otherwise healthy tissue. Thus,
targeting tumor cells---either with a scalpel, radiation, or
chemotherapy---is notoriously difficult. Moreover, drug molecules are
foreign species that are often targeted for removal by the immune
system. They also suffer from poor solubility and can form solid
**emboli** when injected. These solid structures can block vasculature
and lead to loss of oxygen to vital organs. Thus, engineered
nanoparticles which can solubilize therapeutic molecules, evade the
immune system and target cancerous tissue without damaging healthy
tissue are critical tools in anticancer therapy.

#### Characteristics of cancer cells and tumors

Cancer refers to the out-of-control growth of formerly healthy cells
that exhibit either a **congenital abnormality** or **oncogene**, or
genetic defect that arose from some external factor, i.e. sun exposure,
carcinogenic chemicals, or ionizing radiation. Such cells associate with
one another to form a solid mass called a tumor. The presence of a tumor
has many consequences on normal physiological function, not the least of
which is the physical bulk of the tumor itself. This mass presses on
other organs, reroutes blood supply, and consumes space and resources
needed for healthy tissue. Moreover, cancer cells can break free of the
solid mass and take root in other locations in the body in a process
called **metastasis**.

#### Passive targeting

While derived from healthy cells, cancer cells and tumors exhibit
differences from the normal cells in healthy tissue that can be
exploited by particular strategies of drug delivery. For example, tumors
have leaky vasculature, meaning that the walls of the blood vessels are
porous. This hack plumbing job is the basis for the targeting approach
known as **enhanced permeability and retention (EPR)**, see Figure
(13.6). In EPR, nanoparticles of a size small enough to fit through the
leaky sidewalls of the vasculature tend to concentrate in the
extravascular space. Once inside the tumor, such particles are unlikely
to find their way back into the circulatory system (does leaked water
ever end up back inside the pipe?). The EPR effect thus represents a
mode known as **passive targeting**, in which therapeutic molecules
naturally find their ways to the right places.[^13.4.1] Another way in which
the tumor microenvironment is different from that of the surrounding
healthy environment is the pH. Tumor tissue tends to be lower in pH than
the surrounding tissue. Thus, nanoparticles that can be activated by
acid-base mediated reactions may be used to release their drug payload
selectively at the tumor site in a passive targeting manner.

(Figure 13.6) 
>>>image(EPR.png.0)

#### Active targeting

In contrast to the passive targeting approach described above, where no
intervention is needed on the part of the medical provider, active
targeting approaches have also been applied to cancer therapy. For
example, nanoparticles exhibiting ferromagnetic components can be
directed toward the tumor site by the external application of a magnetic
field. Similarly, thermally or photothermally actived nanoparticles can
be engineered to release their drugs only in the vicinity of the tumor
using the external application of heat or light. Tumor cells may also
exhibit unusual chemical signatures on their surfaces, which can be
targeted for destruction by engineered nanoparticles or other biological
structures in a methodology called **cancer immunotherapy**.

### 13.4.2. Types of nanoparticles

Many types of nanoparticles have been used for encapsulates for
therapeutic agents or as therapeutic agents themselves. The earliest
form of nanoparticle drug delivery system is the use of a **liposome**.
A liposome is a self-assembled structure whose basic form is that of a
bilayer vesicle. A bilayer vesicle is superficially similar to a cell
envelope, and bears many of the same features as a micelle. The
structure of a liposome is shown in Figure (13.3). Liposomes can be used
to to encapsulate hydrophilic drugs such as proteins, nucleic acids, and
small molecules bearing a negative or positive charge. They can also be
used to solubilize hydrophobic small molecules, which reside in the
lipophilic skin of the bilayer vesicle. The simplest way to form a
drug-loaded liposome is to take the drug molecules, concentrate them
down by evaporating any solvent, add the amphiphilic lipids, and
re-suspend the drug. The surfaces of liposomes can also be modified
using molecules with a component that inserts into the lipophilic
bilayer. Such liposomes can thus be engineered to present carbohydrates
and proteins at the surface of the molecule (i.e., signaling molecules)
to find their way to the tumor site and/or to release their drug
payloads once there.

#### Polymeric nanoparticles

Another type of drug delivery vehicle is based on polymers. As roughly
spherical blobs containing a high fraction of solvent, polymers in
solution are basically nanoparticles. They can also be engineered to
exhibit the properties of controlled degradation and can be either
loaded with or coated with drug molecules. Polymers can either be
cross-linked or uncrosslinked, and can be in a sense "programmed" to
degrade either under physiological conditions or to remain intact to be
cleared from the system some other way. Cross-linked polymers, like
hydrogel-based nanoparticles, are designed to release their payload
gradually, as water from the bloodstream infiltrates the particles and
dissolves the drugs. Crosslinked and uncrosslinked nanoparticles---and
indeed most engineered drug delivery systems---can also non-selectively
adsorb drug molecules to the surface. Once infused into the patients,
these physisorbed drug molecules tend to release all at once, the
undesirable but sometimes unavoidable phenomenon known as **burst
release**. Given the high ratio of surface area to volume of
nanoparticles, the burst release can actually introduce as many drug
molecules into the bloodstream as are contained in the interior,
depending on the size of the particle and the size of the drug molecule.

#### Inorganic nanoparticles

While it may seem counterintuitive, nanostructures based on metals and
oxides offer many potenitally useful approaches to delivering drug
molecules. For example, metallic nanoparticles exhibit localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) which can cause nanoparticles to heat up.
This approach could either be used to target cancer directly by
effectively burning and killing the cancer cells, or it could be used to
melt a shell of the nanoparticles to release drug molecules from the
interior. The use of ferromagnetic nanoparticles---which might contain
iron or nickel---as a means of guiding them to the target site has
already been discussed in the context of active targeting approaches.

### 13.4.3. Nanoparticles for biomedical imaging

Biomedical imaging includes magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed
tomography (CT), ultrasound, and X-ray imaging. All of these techniques
require or benefit from the use of contrast agents. In many cases, one
wishes to put a contrast agent as close to the site of injury as
possible. If you have ever received an X-ray for a broken bone, you will
recall the little steel ball that they stick to your skin where it
hurts, so that the radiologist knows where to look. Sometimes, targeting
nanoparticles to cancer sites and the sites of injury in imaging studies
serve a similar function. That is, they are designed to migrate to the
site of injury (or tumor).

Thus, nanoparticles exhibiting photothermal, photoemissive, magnetic, or
photoacoustic properties have been used to enhance existing imaging
technologies. As an example, **photoacoustic imaging** is the use of
light pulses to generate periodic fluctuations in temperature which in
turn produces acoustic signals, which, needless to say, are inaudible to
the human ear. Nevertheless, these sound waves can be picked up by a
conventional ultrasound transducer---like the ones used to obtain images
of fetuses during pregnancy. Photoacoustic imaging is enabled by the use
of a molecular dye or nanoparticle that captures light either by
electronic absorption or by localized surface plasmon resonance. After
absorption occurs, the molecule or particle de-excites and in the
process generates a small amount of heat, which is quickly dissipated.
Thus, the frequency of the light pulses become the frequency of the
sound generated. Photoacoustic imaging thus follows the mnemonic of
"light in, sound out."

### 13.4.4. Nanomedicine for vaccine delivery

The COVID-19 pandemic brought to the public eye many methods for
generating an immune response to a novel pathogen, in this case, the
"novel coronavirus," SARS-CoV-2. These approaches for the rapid---at
times scrambling---development of a new vaccine spanned a range of
technologies, including the traditional method of chemical inactivation
of a live virus, the use of adenoviruses to deliver genetic instructions
for the production of proteins found on the surface of SARS-CoV-2, and
the use of mRNA molecules encoding this protein delivered directly to
the cells.[^13.4.2] However, mRNA molecules are readily hydrolyzed---i.e.,
broken down---under physiological conditions. Moreover, once inside the
bloodstream, they are not likely to enter the cell on their own. The use
of **lipid nanoparticles** can address these concerns by (1) providing a
protected environment for the mRNA molecules and (2) having molecules at
the surface that encourage merging with the cell membrane. Once inside
the cell, the mRNA molecules are translated into the spike protein by
the cellular ribosome. These spike proteins circulate in the bloodstream
and are recognized by the immune system, which produces antibodies.

### 13.4.5. Retention and clearance of nanoparticles

Most of the nanoparticles introduced into the bloodstream for either
therapeutic or imaging applications eventually have to be removed. If
left to circulate, such nanoparticles may occlude blood vessels, become
stuck in internal organs, or degrade into unhealthy byproducts. The
process by which normally functioning organs remove the foreign material
over time is called **clearance**. Thus, the nanoparticles must be
engineered such that they remain in the system longer---i.e.,
**retention**. Nanoparticles must have sufficient time in the
bloodstream to give the desired therapeutic effect, while not
overstaying their welcome. The factors which determine what organ system
removes the nanoparticles from the bloodstream include the size,
composition, surface charge, and even shape of the nanoparticles. While
many excellent resources exist for the interested reader, suffice it to
say that very small nanoparticles, smaller than 5 nm, get filtered out
of the bloodstream by the kidneys and are expelled in the urine. Other
particles are engulfed and degraded by cells of the immune system, while
others are destined for the liver, where they are broken down. Larger
particles may be filtered by the spleen, though too much accumulation
there can degrade the function of the spleen. If a particle is destined
for the liver or the spleen, there must be a mechanism to break it down,
otherwise the fine blood vessels located in these organs may be
occluded, which can cause an **infarct**, or death of tissue due to
hypoxia (loss of oxygenation).

#### Section 5: Outlook
The 1960s movie *Fantastic Voyage*, the somewhat more recent children's
TV show *The Magic School Bus*, or the 1987 movie *Innerspace*, depicts
a future where tiny vehicles can enter the human body. In some fictional
works, these micron-sized vehicles are envisioned to attack cancer cells
or other invading species by something like conscious will. While we are
many decades from that kind of reality, some research which hints at
such a future has started to emerge. For example, **microswimmers** have
been created from a variety of materials. These devices often use
chemical species found in the bloodstream or other microenvironments as
fuels for propulsion. As of now, the guidance of these systems is
generally under external control. Moreover, greater functionality could
be achieved if these micron-sized "nanobots" could be scaled down to
truly cellular or even molecular dimensions, could communicate with one
another, and could find their way without external intervention. In
time, however, it seems that such "smart" nanoengineered approaches to
medical puzzles will eventually be developed.
